title: 107_s731
content: The Act may be cited as the "Military Overseas Voter Empowerment Act of 2001". Congress acknowledges the special responsibility to protect the voting rights of military members and their families, with over 2,700,000 stationed away from their home of record. The disenfranchisement of military voters has been recognized since 1952, prompting President Truman to recommend temporary legislation by Congress. Federal legislation is needed to protect the voting rights of military personnel who serve in defense of our Nation, as many face disenfranchisement due to confusing state and local procedures. Federal legislation is needed to protect the voting rights of military personnel who face disenfranchisement due to confusing state and local procedures. This includes a guarantee of residency for military personnel. Article VII of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to ensure that military personnel, when absent from a State due to military orders, do not lose their residency for voting purposes. This includes not being deemed to have acquired residency in another State. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to protect military personnel's residency for voting purposes when absent from a State due to military orders. Extension of registration and balloting rights for absent uniformed services voters to state and local elections. Amendment to the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act requires states to allow absentee voting for state and local offices, process voter registration applications from absent uniformed services voters at least 30 days before the election. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act requires states to allow absentee voting for state and local offices, and process voter registration applications from absent uniformed services voters at least 30 days before the election. Additionally, the heading for title I of the Act is amended by removing "FOR FEDERAL OFFICE". The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act requires states to process applications and absentee ballots from absent uniformed services voters. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act mandates a minimum 30-day period between the availability of absentee ballots and the deadline for submission for absent uniformed services voters. States cannot reject valid absentee ballots based on untimely submission if submitted within the specified timeframe. Additionally, ballots submitted by absent uniformed services voters can only be invalidated for fraud. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act prohibits states from rejecting valid absentee ballots from absent uniformed services voters based on untimely submission. Ballots can only be invalidated for fraud, requiring clear and convincing evidence of fraud in the preparation or casting of the ballot. Lack of witness signature or other identifying information is not sufficient evidence of fraud. This subsection does not affect state ballot submission deadlines. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act prohibits states from rejecting valid absentee ballots from absent uniformed services voters based on untimely submission. States cannot refuse to accept or process voter registration or absentee ballot applications early for federal elections. Additionally, a single application for absentee ballots for all federal elections is required. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act requires states to accept and process absentee ballot applications from absent uniformed services voters and overseas voters for all federal elections if received at least 30 days before the first election of the year. SEC. 6. Granting protections to recently separated uniformed services voters under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act. A new section, SEC. 104A, is added to cover recently separated uniformed services voters. For the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, separated uniformed services voters are treated like absent uniformed services voters for 60 days after separation. Separated uniformed services voter is defined as an individual who was a uniformed services voter before separation and presents proof of separation. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act requires proof that an individual meets specific requirements to vote in an election. A "uniformed services voter" includes members of the uniformed services on active duty or the merchant marine. SEC. 7. ELECTRONIC VOTING DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. The Secretary of Defense will conduct a demonstration project allowing absent uniformed services voters to cast ballots electronically in the 2002 general election. The project will be coordinated with State election officials, and a report analyzing the project will be submitted to Congress by June 1, 2003. A report analyzing the project will be submitted to Congress by June 1, 2003. The project is appropriate for continuing on an expanded basis during the next regularly scheduled general election for Federal office. The Act and its amendments will apply to elections after the enactment date.
